body:
Have you measured that this improves your propagation time more than just
connecting to a few fast peers? By the time you have sent out your block to
100 well-connected peers, the last ones to get it likely could have already
gotten it from eachother faster than from you, as more fast peers means you
suddenly need to do a lot more work to keep up with the sudden burst of
network packets to broadcast the block.

In any case, I do not think this serves the best interests of users of the
software. We have had several cases of people thinking that more
connections means faster confirmations of their transactions, or "better
validated" blocks.

In the past we have also seen problems with the network running out of
connectable slots, so we have actively avoided options for people to
overwelm the network with connections. I'm very aware an attacker could do
this anyhow, but this is more about preventing people from hurting the
network while incorrectly believing it benefits them (for non-miners, a
single connection to a non-compromised is as good as any higher number).

I believe this equally would not actually benefit you.
